<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 220, 618]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 477, 89]]<|/det|>
A battery provides energy to an electric car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 756, 120]]<|/det|>
The electric car has an acceleration of \(2.9 \text{m/s}^2\) when it moves from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 613, 135]]<|/det|>
The combined mass of the car and its driver is \(1600 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 181, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 628, 166]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time taken to reach a speed of \(28 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 255, 922, 273]]<|/det|>
<form>time = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 287, 181, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 287, 663, 306]]<|/det|>
Calculate the force required to produce this acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 364, 920, 382]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 396, 181, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 724, 413]]<|/det|>
Calculate the kinetic energy of the car when its speed is \(28 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 520, 922, 539]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 552, 148, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 892, 586]]<|/det|>
The time taken for the car battery to be recharged from zero charge to full charge is \(8.3 \text{h}\). The charge is delivered to the battery by a charger with a current of \(32 \text{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 597, 532, 616]]<|/det|>
Calculate the charge supplied by the charger.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 721, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
<form>charge = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 753, 144, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 753, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
Under ideal conditions, the car can travel a maximum distance of \(390 \text{km}\) when the battery is fully charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 800, 915, 817]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 865, 922, 884]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 621, 89]]<|/det|>

When the bowl is removed from the freezer, it contains ice at a temperature of \(-18.0^\circ \text{C}\). The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 477, 855, 496]]<|/det|>
Describe and explain what happens to the needle of the sensitive galvanometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 735, 471]]<|/det|> Fig. 10.1 shows a graph of the count rate **due to this sample** against time. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 477, 789, 794]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 811, 537, 829]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 842, 146, 860]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 841, 873, 860]]<|/det|> Explain why the readings in Table 10.1 are **not** the same as those plotted on the graph. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 903, 920, 920]]<|/det|> [2]
